title.narrative: Bridging the Gaps

description.narrative: Bridging the Gaps (2011-2020) was an SRHR and HIV programme that worked with the following key population groups: sex workers, people who use drugs, and lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

Bridging the Gaps – an alliance of nine international organisations and networks and more than 80 local and regional organisations in 15 countries – concluded activities in December 2020, after ten years of programming. From 2011 until 2020, we made significant contributions towards ending the AIDS epidemic among sex workers, people who use drugs and LGBT people around the world. The programme worked towards a society where key populations are empowered, their human rights are respected and they have access to quality services tailored to their needs.

Sex workers, lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people and people who use drugs (PWUD) are significantly more vulnerable to HIV infection than the general population. More than 45% of new HIV infections occur among key populations, yet in most countries they have the least access to prevention, treatment and care. The Bridging the Gaps programme worked to increase access to essential HIV services for key populations, and strengthen their capacity to hold governments accountable while contributing to the full realisation of their human rights.
Sex workers , lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people and people who use drugs are typically 10 to 20 times more likely to become infected by HIV while only 8% have access to HIV services. The denial of human rights has a negative impact on their health.

The Bridging the Gaps approach:
Key populations in the driver’s seat The most effective HIV programming involves key populations in all levels of decision-making, as confirmed by the World Health Organization in its ‘Consolidated guidelines on HIV prevention, diagnosis, treatment and care for key populations’. This is why key population communities were firmly in the driver’s seat of the Bridging the Gaps programme at all levels, from governance to implementation.
Linking human rights and health Drug use, sex work and non-conforming sexual orientation or gender identity are stigmatised and criminalised in many countries. As a result, HIV prevention, treatment, care and support services and other sexual and reproductive health services are less accessible for these key populations. This causes them to be disproportionally affected by HIV and AIDS compared to the general population.
Linking key populations Through the sharing of best practices, lessons learnt and advocacy tools, and the piloting of joint solutions with our regional and country partners, Bridging the Gaps addressed the common challenges faced by sex workers, LGBT people and PWUD in accessing HIV prevention, treatment, care and support.
Linking in-country community level work with global advocacy Global policy changes need to be fuelled from the ground up. Civil society organisations can only scale up advocacy initiatives and service provision when structural and policy barriers are addressed and removed.

sector.narrative: Bridging the Gaps STD control including HIV/AIDS

5 Human Rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: Human rights violation cases acted on is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of responded to, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 4 Participation of partner organization in or organization of local

description.narrative: Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations that participate in meetings. Meetings are defined as advocacy meetings with local national regional or global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations. Meetings are advocacy meetings with local/national/regional/global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 1 Service provision to Key Population Members

description.narrative: Service provision to key population members measures the number of services used by key population members. This is done through 6 indicators that respectively measure the number of testing services, treatment services, PWUD specific medical harm reduction services, other health services meaning condom distribution, social services and legal support services used by key population members.

title.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services

description.narrative: 1A # of KP members using testing services (disaggregated by age) everything falling under voluntary counselling and testing is part of this indicator, testing for TB, STIs Age group 24 and under

title.narrative: 1B # of KP members using treatment services

description.narrative: 1B # of KP members using treatment services (disaggregated by age) ART, STI and TB treatment Age group 24 and under

title.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services

description.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services (disaggregated by age) including needle exchange, OST, OD prevention, PWUD specific counselling Age group 24 and under

title.narrative: 1D # of KP members using other health services (condom distribution)

description.narrative: 1D # of KP members using other health services (disaggregated by age) (condom distribution) Age group 24 and under

title.narrative: 1E # of KP members using social services

description.narrative: 1E # of KP members using social services (disaggregated by age) including self-help groups, psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services. Age group 24 and under

title.narrative: 1F # of KP members using legal support services

description.narrative: 1F # of KP members using legal support services (disaggregated by age). Age group 24 and under

title.narrative: 2 Trained Service Providers

description.narrative: Trained service providers uses 2 indicators. 2A measures the # of service providers trained. Services provided are social services, incl psychosocial support, health education & promotion, online counselling, health NGO or public sector services. The counselling under VCT services is excluded. Service providers with local partners and indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners are counted. 2B measures the # of legal service providers trained incl paralegal services

title.narrative: 2A # service providers trained

description.narrative: 2A # of service providers trained. This is the number of individual service providers meaning staff members, trained by alliance partner and/or by a country partner. Total # is the number of people trained by alliance partner and number of people trained by partners. Service providers provide social (including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services), or health(NGO or public sector) services. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners (e.g. other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc).

title.narrative: 2B # legal service providers trained

description.narrative: 2B # legal service providers trained including paralegal services
